clues.text: Whitewater & touring are the most common types of this vessel
In 1979 this rock group topped the charts with "My Sharona"
This Scottish word for church dates back over 800 years
In England, it's a telephone booth; in the U.S., a small multi-sided structure such as a newsstand
This coin is 1/100th of a ruble
Her middle intial B. stood for Brownell
When she married Henry Stanton in 1840, she insisted on omitting the word "obey" from the marriage vows
It's the number of the U.S. Constitutional amendment that gave women the right to vote
A utilitarian philosopher who worked with suffrage societies, he wrote 1869's "The Subjection of Women"
The first woman to run for president, she was a proponent of free love as well as suffrage
This '60s style was named for the flared shape of the jeans' lower portion
Jeans were originally called "waist-high" these, as distinguished from "bib" ones
Levi's first famous line, it was probably the item number Levi Strauss assigned in his wholesale catalog
In the disco era many said, "Uh-oh, Sergio" as they squeezed into this brand of designer jeans
Introduced in 1947, this brand was designed by Philadelphia tailor "Rodeo Ben" Lichtenstein
Since marrying Broadway actress Rachel Miner, he's no longer "Home Alone"
Nelson Mandela's 1998 wedding was officiated by a team of clerics led by this Anglican archbishop
560 guests (& 200 million TV viewers) watched Sophie Rhys-Jones marry this charming prince
Bryant Gumbel served as Best Man in 1998 when this "Today" co-host married model Annette Roque
Daughter Laura Dern was Maid of Honor when she wed a businessman on Valentine's Day, 1999
To change dollars into pesos, or Christians into Jews
From Latin for "change", this type of change in DNA causes sickle cell anemia
The movement of starlight toward the long end of the spectrum is called the "Red" this
"Directional" change the Supreme Court makes when it takes the opposite view from a lower court
This 6-syllable word refers specifically to the changing of bread & wine into the body & blood of Christ

Johnny Logan:
"We're honoring one of the all-time greats in baseball, Stan" (The Man) him. "He's immoral"
This Hall of Fame 1970s Reds catcher "was thinking about making a comeback until I pulled a muscle vacuuming"
He made "Bartlett's" with "If people don't want to come out to the ballpark, nobody's going to stop them"
At a dinner, Redskins RB John Riggins begged this Supreme Court justice, "Come on, Sandy baby, loosen up"
This 1950s Yankee mgr. said of a pitcher, "He don't smoke, he don't drink, he don't chase women & he don't win"

clues.text:
A really cool dwelling for an Eskimo:
GL

A birthstone:
PL

A woodwind instrument:
B

An African country:
GND

A woolly mammal:
LPC
Born October 9, 1940 in Liverpool, he died tragically December 8, 1980 in New York City
He was born January 15, 1929 in Atlanta & died in Memphis April 4, 1968
A profile of this film director says he was born in Britain in 1899 & died in Los Angeles in 1980
He was born on an Army post in Little Rock in 1880 & faded away at a D.C. hospital in 1964
Born in Houston in 1905, he died en route from Acapulco to Houston in 1976; his money couldn't save him
This pigment in blood transports oxygen
Sometimes caused by tooth grinding, the disorder known by these 3 letters can lead to a clicking jaw
Microscopic shaggy hairs called villi line the walls of this digestive organ
In the arm, the name of this muscle precedes brachii; in the leg, femoris
The human brain has billions of connections across these gaps between neurons

1972:
Diana Ross in this biopic

1980:
Dolly Parton in this workplace comedy

2001:
Mariah Carey in this shiny misfire

2002:
Britney Spears in this "road" movie

1993:
Janet Jackson in this urban drama
This Nabokov nymphet first appears peering over dark glasses
Isadora Wing is the lusty heroine of this 1973 Erica Jong bestseller
Becky Thatcher is in "Tom Sawyer"; this Becky is the heroine of "Vanity Fair"
This title heroine tries to set up her friend Harriet with Mr. Elton & is dismayed when Elton proposes to her instead
This Sue Grafton detective was once part of the Santa Teresa Police Department

clues.text:
John Keats:
"A thing of Jeopardy! is a joy forever"

Percy Bysshe Shelley:
"If winter comes, can Jeopardy! be far behind?"

Carl Sandburg:
"The Jeopardy! comes on little cat feet"

Lewis Carroll:
"'Twas Jeopardy!, and the slithy toves did gyre and gimble in the wabe"

Ernest L. Thayer:
"The outlook wasn't brilliant for the Jeopardy! nine that day"

rounds.text: Woodrow Wilson said this man had enough genius to be immortal & "unschooled passion enough to have made him infamous"
